turn.text: Now what, which is higher, would you say I came in the 30 and someone else came in the 35, which would make the higher contribution?

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: The older age would make the higher contribution because there is a less period of time to accumulate sufficient funds to pay for your retirement.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But also, there is a less longevity.

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: No, because you are retiring at 65 either.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Some 35 years old has a less or a greater longevity I guess.

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: From 35 he does but not, that they are all retiring at the same age of 60 or 65.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But longevity talks about when they have to die?

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And you say the one who comes into the workforce as an older person pays a higher.

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: A higher contribution.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And you are going to pay for fewer years.

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: Right.
No, he is paying for the same retirement.
He is going to get the same result but he is only, anybody’s got that fewer years that to.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He is going to make payments for fewer years.

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Oliphant let me put it in another way.
Are all of these other things, decided before the additional amount is prolonged?
I mean, the age of the employee et cetera, are all of those put in there before you think that deal?

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: No, well --.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You take into account a whole lot of things.

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: Right and then.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You take the deduction in front or at the end?

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: We take the contribution and the 14.84% was just an average which was figured for purposes of this lawsuit, that longevity is a function of age and sex.
And in order to determine that, we would go to the actuarial tables.
And from the actuarial tables, it is factored into the contribution rate.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Oliphant, does the record explain how the differing contributions for each year were calculated?

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: I do not think it does your honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, we cannot tell the extent to which the longevity figured as of the age of entering the employment of the company.
To what extent age affected the contribution rate?

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: No your honor because--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the record does not tell us.

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: The interrogatories may but I do not think they do your honor.
This came up on summary judgment and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Who made them?
Oh, they made motion?

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: They made the motion and conceded the accuracy of the actuarial tables in the good faith of the department.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The benefits that are calculated are a function of what?
Is it at the number of -- Tell me how again.
How is the benefit calculated?

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: Years of service and the retirement age.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not -- your salary level, makes no difference.

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: And salary level, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is salary average over the period or at retirement age?

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: No, the last year of the service, the final average salary for the last year of service multiplied by 2% or, it is a little higher now, 2.1% for each year of service.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the contributions are a percentage of salary always?

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the percentage depends on a, your sex and b, the age in which you have joined the company.

turn.speaker: david_j_oliphant
turn.label: Mr. David J. Oliphant
turn.text: That is correct.
I think the important thing to recognize in closing is that, it is not just sex, it is sex plus age longevity and that as in Gilbert is a factor other than sex just as pregnancy was.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentleman.
The case is submitted.
